Definitions.Text: Things that are new.
Definitions.Example: Out with the old, in with the new.

Definitions.Text: Recently made, or created.
Definitions.Example: This is a new scratch on my car!   The band just released a new album.

Definitions.Text: Additional; recently discovered.
Definitions.Example: We turned up some new evidence from the old files.

Definitions.Text: Current or later, as opposed to former.
Definitions.Example: My new car is much better than my previous one, even though it is older.   We had been in our new house for five years by then.

Definitions.Text: Used to distinguish something established more recently, named after something or some place previously existing.
Definitions.Example: New Bond Street is an extension of Bond Street.

Definitions.Text: In original condition; pristine; not previously worn or used.
Definitions.Example: Are you going to buy a new car or a second-hand one?

Definitions.Text: Refreshed, reinvigorated, reformed.
Definitions.Example: That shirt is dirty. Go and put on a new one.   I feel like a new person after a good night's sleep.   After the accident, I saw the world with new eyes.

Definitions.Text: Newborn.
Definitions.Example: My sister has a new baby, and our mother is excited to finally have a grandchild.

Definitions.Text: Of recent origin; having taken place recently.
Definitions.Example: I can't see you for a while; the pain is still too new.   Did you see the new King Lear at the theatre?

Definitions.Text: Strange, unfamiliar or not previously known.
Definitions.Example: The idea was new to me.   I need to meet new people.

Definitions.Text: Recently arrived or appeared.
Definitions.Example: Have you met the new guy in town?   He is the new kid at school.

Definitions.Text: Inexperienced or unaccustomed at some task.
Definitions.Example: Don't worry that you're new at this job; you'll get better with time.   I'm new at this business.

Definitions.Text: (of a period of time) Next; about to begin or recently begun.
Definitions.Example: We expect to grow at 10% annually in the new decade.

Definitions.Text: Newly (especially in composition).
Definitions.Example: new-born, new-formed, new-found, new-mown

Definitions.Text: As new; from scratch.
Definitions.Example: They are scraping the site clean to build new.

Definitions.Text: To gain knowledge from a bad experience so as to improve.
Definitions.Example: learn from one's mistakes

Definitions.Text: To study.
Definitions.Example: I learn medicine.

Definitions.Text: To come to know; to become informed of; to find out.
Definitions.Example: He just learned that he will be sacked.

Definitions.Text: The collection of words a person knows and uses.
Definitions.Example: My Russian vocabulary is very limited.

Definitions.Text: The stock of words used in a particular field.
Definitions.Example: The vocabulary of social sciences is often incomprehensible to ordinary people.

Definitions.Text: The words of a language collectively.
Definitions.Example: The vocabulary of any language is influenced by contacts with other cultures.

Definitions.Text: A body of words, and set of methods of combining them (called a grammar), understood by a community and used as a form of communication.
Definitions.Example: Deaf and mute people communicate using languages like ASL.

Definitions.Text: The ability to communicate using words.
Definitions.Example: the gift of language

Definitions.Text: A sublanguage: the slang of a particular community or jargon of a particular specialist field.
Definitions.Example: legal language;   the language of chemistry

Definitions.Text: The expression of thought (the communication of meaning) in a specified way; that which communicates something, as language does.
Definitions.Example: body language;   the language of the eyes

Definitions.Text: The particular words used in a speech or a passage of text.
Definitions.Example: The language he used to talk to me was obscene.

Definitions.Text: A greeting (salutation) said when meeting someone or acknowledging someone’s arrival or presence.
Definitions.Example: Hello, everyone.

Definitions.Text: A greeting used when answering the telephone.
Definitions.Example: Hello? How may I help you?

Definitions.Text: A call for response if it is not clear if anyone is present or listening, or if a telephone conversation may have been disconnected.
Definitions.Example: Hello? Is anyone there?

Definitions.Text: Used sarcastically to imply that the person addressed or referred to has done something the speaker or writer considers to be foolish.
Definitions.Example: You just tried to start your car with your cell phone. Hello?

Definitions.Text: An expression of puzzlement or discovery.
Definitions.Example: Hello! What’s going on here?

Definitions.Text: A physical injury caused by heat, cold, electricity, radiation or caustic chemicals.
Definitions.Example: She had second-degree burns from falling in the bonfire.

Definitions.Text: A sensation resembling such an injury.
Definitions.Example: chili burn from eating hot peppers

Definitions.Text: The act of burning something with fire.
Definitions.Example: They're doing a controlled burn of the fields.

Definitions.Text: Physical sensation in the muscles following strenuous exercise, caused by build-up of lactic acid.
Definitions.Example: One and, two and, keep moving; feel the burn!

Definitions.Text: The operation or result of burning or baking, as in brickmaking.
Definitions.Example: They have a good burn.

Definitions.Text: To cause to be consumed by fire.
Definitions.Example: He burned his manuscript in the fireplace.

Definitions.Text: To be consumed by fire, or in flames.
Definitions.Example: He watched the house burn.

Definitions.Text: To overheat so as to make unusable.
Definitions.Example: He burned the toast. The blacksmith burned the steel.

Definitions.Text: To become overheated to the point of being unusable.
Definitions.Example: The grill was too hot and the steak burned.

Definitions.Text: To make or produce by the application of fire or burning heat.
Definitions.Example: to burn a hole;  to burn letters into a block

Definitions.Text: To injure (a person or animal) with heat or chemicals that produce similar damage.
Definitions.Example: She burned the child with an iron, and was jailed for ten years.

Definitions.Text: To sunburn.
Definitions.Example: She forgot to put on sunscreen and burned.

Definitions.Text: To consume, injure, or change the condition of, as if by action of fire or heat; to affect as fire or heat does.
Definitions.Example: to burn the mouth with pepper

Definitions.Text: To be hot, e.g. due to embarrassment.
Definitions.Example: The child's forehead was burning with fever.  Her cheeks burned with shame.

Definitions.Text: To cause to combine with oxygen or other active agent, with evolution of heat; to consume; to oxidize.
Definitions.Example: A human being burns a certain amount of carbon at each respiration.  to burn iron in oxygen

Definitions.Text: To combine energetically, with evolution of heat.
Definitions.Example: Copper burns in chlorine.

Definitions.Text: To write data to a permanent storage medium like a compact disc or a ROM chip.
Definitions.Example: We’ll burn this program onto an EEPROM one hour before the demo begins.

Definitions.Text: To betray.
Definitions.Example: The informant burned him.

Definitions.Text: To insult or defeat.
Definitions.Example: I just burned you again.

Definitions.Text: To waste (time); to waste money or other resources.
Definitions.Example: The company has burned more than a million dollars a month this year.

Definitions.Text: In certain games, to approach near to a concealed object which is sought.
Definitions.Example: You're cold... warm... hot... you're burning!

Definitions.Text: To be without, to need, to require.
Definitions.Example: My life lacks excitement.

Definitions.Text: To be short (of or for something).
Definitions.Example: He'll never lack for company while he's got all that money.

Definitions.Text: (of people) Favoured by luck; fortunate; having good success or good fortune
Definitions.Example: The downed pilot is very lucky to be alive.

Definitions.Text: Producing, or resulting in, good fortune
Definitions.Example: a lucky cast

Definitions.Text: A male monarch; a man who heads a monarchy. If it's an absolute monarchy, then he is the supreme ruler of his nation.
Definitions.Example: Henry VIII was the king of England from 1509 to 1547.

Definitions.Text: A powerful or majorly influential person.
Definitions.Example: Howard Stern styled himself as the "king of all media".

Definitions.Text: Something that has a preeminent position.
Definitions.Example: In times of financial panic, cash is king.

Definitions.Text: A component of certain games.
A king skin.
Definitions.Example: Oi mate, have you got kings?

Definitions.Text: A male dragonfly; a drake.
A king-sized bed.
A male person.
To crown king, to make (a person) king.
To rule over as king.
To perform the duties of a king.
To assume or pretend preeminence (over); to lord it over.
To promote a piece of draughts/checkers that has traversed the board to the opposite side, that piece subsequently being permitted to move backwards as well as forwards.
To dress and perform as a drag king.
